meanings.definition: To force or drive someone to do something
meanings.sent1: The strong wind can compel the leaves to dance in the air.
meanings.sent2: The teacher's strict rules compel the students to follow instructions.
meanings.sent3: The mischievous squirrel tried to compel the acorns to jump out of the tree.
meanings.sent4: The haunting melody seemed to compel the audience to sway in unison.
meanings.sent5: The urgent message will compel everyone to evacuate immediately.

meanings.definition: To make someone feel obligated to do something
meanings.sent1: The heartfelt plea may compel him to reconsider his decision.
meanings.sent2: His sense of duty will compel him to help those in need.
meanings.sent3: The delicious aroma of freshly baked cookies can compel even the strongest will.
meanings.sent4: The beauty of the sunset seemed to compel her to stay a little longer.
meanings.sent5: The promise of adventure will compel them to embark on a journey.
